Let's retire while we can still do it gracefully. /end

This would be the greatest act of creation in human history, and one of the greatest moral victories of all time. To *make possible* a future where our culture has no place, and then step aside for it, for the sake of humanity and our world.

Coming from Canada, which achieved full democracy and freedom through patient negotiation, I am perhaps biased. But why not imagine our culture deliberately *getting out of the way* of the one that's our necessary successor? A golden sunset for Modernism? /9

Rather than imagining a violent overthrow of the status quo, I'll propose something utterly different, based on a paradigm that's initially not likely to make sense to you. Rather than our civilization being destroyed, what would happen if it... retired? /8

Getting there, though, is the problem, and most of the SF I've read that looks at such a future imagines the transition as rough, violent--even cataclysmic. Mark gave me an idea for a different vision of how it could come about. /7

Except again, *we* can't. We have to give over to a culture that will be able to. And we can certainly be its designers and parents. A lot of current "hopepunk" and "solarpunk" is about imagining what that post-us culture is going to look like. Which is great. /6

... Just realize that 90% of our economic activity is or is soon to be unnecessary for sustaining our lives comfortably. We work, in other words, to sustain growth and because everything we make is disposable by design. We can do a lot less, and still thrive /5

It's perfectly possible to do less on this world and live well. Again, this is not something this civilization is capable of. Systemic inequality prevents that. But we don't have to imagine some gray Soviet redistribution of wealth... /4

We constantly talk about "what more we can do" to shift to a greener/circular/sustainable economy. But how can we *do* anything more to solve our problem when *doing* itself is the problem? We need, in fact, to be doing less, not more. /3

The next civilization is the one capable of thriving indefinitely on this planet without destroying its biosphere. It is not our civilization, which is based on extraction, growth, and "externalities," i.e. pollution. We're fooling ourselves if we think *we* can change.
